messages.content: Example DAO UI: https://client.aragon.org/#/governance.aragonproject.eth

- slow af
- voting ui is insane (why do i need to see the shasum on every proposal)
- yes/no bars are nonsensically low (if everything's only getting 3%, calibrate the bar to show me something useful)
- home looks like a fisher-price toy
overall, pretty cool, one of the best UIs i have seen.

Some  other UI for proposals and voting:
- https://www.mintscan.io/cosmos/proposals
- https://junoscan.com/proposals
- https://ping.pub/juno/gov

Actual DAOs:
- https://dao.molochdao.com/
- https://www.thelao.io/
- https://flamingodao.xyz/
- https://www.raidguild.org/
Already mentioned, but Aragon is probably the best tool for making a DAO today: https://client.aragon.org/
It's not a perfect UI, but a lot of people use it.
Not for a lot of these projects, you need MetaMask, but you don't actually have to have ETH to explore.
Daus Haus has become a popular UI for DAO contracts in the Ethereum ecosystem: https://app.daohaus.club/
Last but not least, Commonwealth has become a popular tool for DAOs and blockchain governance: https://commonwealth.im/
It has some extra tools around discussions, etc.
i've been using ping.pub, it's pretty good.

high-level observation: there are clearly a lot of reusable UI components between all of these (i.e., the UIs are overall quite similar), and i assume a lot of work was replicated between all of the projects you're listing here. it would be very much in the spirit of the cosmos ecosystem to have reusable governance UI modules.

one thing i mentioned in #frontend and have slept on since last night: 

frontend validation of contract JSON may be one of the most enduring pieces of this codebase. the visual style and defaults may change as norms and values around DAO creation shift over the coming years. (hell, cosmos RPC messages themselves may change). but a framework to reliably (i.e., works across edge cases) and durably (i.e., works across upstream changes) validate proposals before actually proposing them is critical.

there are two kinds of validation: (1) validating that JSON coheres to RPC message spec; and (2) validating that the state after the proposal---were to it to pass---would be sane and desirable.
we're thinking about (1) in frontend, but (2) is just as important, and less obvious how to do from a design perspective
it's just pre-dinner in my timezone so excuse the potential dumbness but how would one go about 2? some kind of dry run mechanism?
yeah, that's what i'm imagining

it would be a little crazy, but not too crazy. you take the current chain state (easy enough) and you've got the state machine (smart contract), so you should be able to run the messages through it and produce the next state. the simplest thing would effectively be an off-chain RPC that spits out the result of dry runs
it would require the DAO to run some web2 infra, but if you think about it like integration testing for your DAO proposals, i'd say it's worth it!
yeah you would have to basically do it as a data validation step
depending on the size of snapshot, could be Kinda Okay or A Massive Pain and i'm not sure which, without thinking about it some more
I think Terra has something like this. Feel it would be really cool to figure out, but as a v2.
agreed. it may also make sense to split off from DAO DAO somewhat, as hypothetical transactions are broadly useful for CI on smart contracts!
Think this would be a good Hack Juno project, but yeah a distraction from our core work here for the moment.
agree
it's on my longer-term docket
re: proposal templates. a rough analogy is what grafana does for SQL. you can create some pretty sophisticated queries using their GUI.
but you can also press the little pencil icon and switch over to editing the SQL itself (understanding that custom queries can't always be represented in the GUI).

messages.content: wow, looks fantastic!

These look great. A couple of practical things I've run into fiddling around with the front-end data management.

1) There's a hierarchy: DAO->Proposals->Messages
2) Proposals are going to be in a "draft" state while they're being created and before they're proposed to the chain. For v0, that means in-memory in the browser (or possibly localstorage). 
3) Proposals could have multiple spend messages, a mint message, multiple custom JSON blocks, etc. 
4) In draft mode, messages can be added and removed from the proposal.
5) Once proposed to the DAO there are specific finite states a proposal can progress to (voting, approved, rejected, executed)

Individual messages can (and ideally should) have custom UI for common types. Right now only spend messages do.

Oh yes – thanks for added information on the draft mode!
What do you mean by message(s)? I was assuming that for v1 there would only be one block text that would serve as a Proposal description. Are you thinking about the "messaging" in a different way?
Current wireframe model for a proposal, minus the save to draft action as a reference
Messages in the case are the messages that will be executed on chain. It's a little confusing.
In other words, that big JSON box.

That JSON editor is pretty heavy weight. It's demand-loaded so it shouldn't hurt our initial load times, but let's be careful about just how much of that kind of thing we want to pile on. I don't want to do a whole lot more in this area before we do our v1 design implementation.

messages.content: honest/non-trolling question: why do we support both DAOs and multisigs? is there something multisigs can do that DAOs can't?
Not everything needs a token.
Sometimes you just want a small group that votes on stuff.
Even in the context of token based DAOs, you may have "teams" break out that request funds from the main DAO.
Multisigs are useful for such things.
Some people then ask the question, "why do you need token based DAOs?"
Think there are a lot of answers to this question...
1. Economic incentives are extremely powerful
2. These allow for potentially more fluid and open membership
3. Easier to create business models, etc.
In the future, we may break them into more separate UIs, but for now I think it's easier to build them together since they share so many components.

all of this makes sense from the perspective of engineering, but i'm not sure that users need to know the difference.

they come to us, they click "Start an organization," and they tick off the features they need their organization to have, along with links to information about what those features mean for them, when they might want to use them, what they should keep in mind. whether it produces a DAO or a multisig under the hood is only interesting to some...

(we can document that, under the hood, one is a DAO with cw20 tokens and one is a multisig. but i don't think we need to *require* users to learn this difference, especially not right away.).
Interesting.
i give a big +1 to supporting both (especially after this chat), but i would actually advocate for making them *even more the same* in the UI.
i feel pretty strongly about this.
willing to be convinced otherwise though.
Yeah, I think we'll get there.
Design is a journey.
Need to solidify some aspects of the UI, then I think we could embark on making them more similar.

messages.content: There was some discussion about this yesterday; if we can impose a convention on the contract messages themselves (i.e., if they have a "type" that is unique) then we can build a registry that maps each to a default template, and alternative frontends can build their own as they see fit. ("Oh, it's a `buy a constitution` message! I'll render it on a parchment paper background")

Some of my earlier implementations of proposal editing had a part/whole UI similar to the left-nav for DAOs and proposals. In other words the "proposal" item on the left nav would be expandable to list the messages inside it, and clicking on each would show a message-specific editor.
(Or, if we don't actually isolate the messages in the main proposal details view, we could at least scroll to and focus the selected message)
so before we land any of this new design work we're going to need to figure out what we want to do for a homepage 🙂

Hey guys recently dove in DAO DAO a bit for the first time and made a little list of feedback from my experiences. I'm familiar with crypto concepts but new to DAO things. Also aware that this isn't the final product and a lot of this feedback could already be solved in the figma file.

```
General
- Clicking on wallet address shouldn't disconnect you, connect/disconnect should be its own button
- Places where users interact with addresses should be displayed and behave the same. Currently 3 styles at: left panel address, DAO page address, DAO proposal page address. 
- Create DAO or multisig could be on the left panel with the other always-present links
- Would be useful to see the amount of funds in the connected wallet as another indicator that you're using the intended wallet
- Adding a visual indicator to the top left logo that you're on Juno mainnet or testnet would be helpful

DAO Browsing
- Searching and sorting is desired
- More general stats under "overview" would be cool or just kill it the panel and give me more space to display more DAOs

DAO Creation/Management
- Ability to change my DAO description and image after creation
- The manage staking UI could be in the panel instead of a pop up
- The "You have # unstaked" message could be at the top but should be dismissible
- On creating a DAO page: more tooltips around what the settings mean or how it affects the DAO, even if they are very simple.
- Some way to tag the topic or purpose of your DAO would be really useful for browsing
- Feel like “If I didn't airdrop someone tokens, how do others get the DAO tokens?” could be a common question ```

Let me know if anything is unclear, thanks!

messages.content: You can make comments on it!
fantastic ty. Should be fun to build UI-wise
Feedback round 1:
"ok, the DAO DAO playground page 1 should either support markdown hyperlinks (which the current one does NOT support) or it should have a separate line for the socials (url, twitter or whatnot)."
"The language around DAO versus Multisig is helpful."
The "example roles and allocations" is reasonable. It is probably not incomprehensible to people, and they can just click on it. It seems ok as a helper mechanic.
I don't understand the difference between a core team member and an advisor. It creates anxiety for me. My brain asks questions like "oh, are advisors not able to vote?"

I don't understand the term "threshold". I imagine this means that there is a plebiscite - ie: something that demands the full attention of every participant. And I imagine there is a time limit. 

And I imagine that it is a "yes or no" type vote - or a vote to "do a thing" versus "not do a thing". And I imagine that of the participants who vote, if 51% of those participants vote in one direction, then that direction carries.

Or, perhaps a threshold means that 51% of the total available votes must vote. 

Or maybe that is a quorum.

Maybe a threshold is that the plurality of a vote in one direction is the direction of the vote - but ALSO there must be at least some percentage of total possible votes in that direction. I also imagine that a vote is proportionate to number of tokens in a linear fashion.

I also imagine there is no kind of run off voting or tie breaking because the votes are only for A or B. In classical voting schemes you may have two good choices, but also a bad third choice, and sometimes the bad third choice can spoil the first two choices - so they invented all kinds of variations of past the post voting.
I also wonder why voting is configured *globally* on the whole DAO rather than on each vote. I guess this is because bad actors could create really bullshit voting conditions.
Ok, otherwise good.
Yes. :) Adding socials is also a really great idea. We can do that with the new contracts.
Good point. Perhaps the wording we should use here is "initial members".

Here's a WIP list of how many governance mechanizms there are:
```Basics:
- Propose/Vote
  - Minimum Choices: Approve, Reject, Abstain
  - Choices: Assent, Go along, Reservation, Stand aside, Block
  - REF: https://www.uua.org/leaderlab/consensus-model-decision-making-overview
- Weighted (Group Council, Token Staking)
- Private (Commit/Reveal)
- Quadratic
- Cyclical (Commit, Adjust, Finalize) - Similar to state channel
- Bias injected (elected expert weighted, working group weighted/proposed)
- Gasless signaling
- insured binding execution
- free proposal creation
- range voting
- multi-choice voting
- zk-voting
- draft proposals
- multisig
- conviction voting (buckets)```
many of which don't necessarily require a token - which could ultimately help governance diversity

Does log in with Ethereum support eip1271 multisigs?

What if I am a signer in a multisig and want to individually log in, using the multisig as a shared account?

Key management going multi-player has interesting implications for smart contracts, wallets and apps

messages.content: it's not crazy to imagine a 'family account' being a 1-of-n multisig. that's effectively how our family email address/lastpass works.
what ux metaphors will make that legible is a separate question.
so there would be a series of limits, like chmod for different activities
single signers in a multisig can:
log in, view balances
multisigners can:
withdraw funds
I've been thinking a lot about chmod because of the continual similarities I see in phpbb boards and discord forums and having multiple users with lots of different permission styles
also thinking about different authentication types - for instance, i had a wiki for a while that could be edited if I followed you on twitter.
the idea was that if i followed you, there would implicit trust that you could edit the wiki, and also that I'd be able to see who edited it (because you could sign in with twitter to edit the wiki)
but no spam, then. unless someone's account got hacked and then they somehow knew about the wiki and then used it to log into the wiki (which would be a lot of hoops and knowledge)
I'm thinking about Keplr/Metamask logins in the same way - the tokens you have in your wallet should allow you to access read/write in similar ways
a whole kind of distributed chmod
"if you're a part of these multisigs you should be able to see x content"
interesting!
i like the gated permissions by # of signers
single | sign - read / view / export single transaction history (like for taxes) / write proposal
multi | withdraw funds / send funds / transfer / export multi history

These are key questions.

idea re: DAO DAO registry:

DAO DAO maintains a Registry, which DAOs to hold a unique name by which their DAO will be findable. (e.g., `pressdao` grants me daodao.zone/pressdao).

Among names in the Registry, the DAO DAO selects which are Promoted. Promoted DAOs appear on the daodao.zone webapp, at various levels of explorability. 

For the Browse page, only DAOs with a registered name are visible/searchable. 

The only curation job of DAO DAO is to seize a DAO's name and blocklist it from the Registry. (The DAO continues to exist; it's even visible on the DAO DAO page, which is just a contract visualizer. It just loses its name.).

Advantages:
- Gives a concrete utility for the DAO DAO token, one you can place an economic value on.
- Is an approach to moderation that splits the difference between DAO DAO-as-a-DAO-explorer and DAO DAO-as-a-DAO-platform. 
- Could provide a speedup to the browse UI, which relies on an as-of-now pretty slow RPC query.

Disadvantages:
- Makes us potentially liable for what DAOs do, as we're doing something more like 'curating.'
- Could lead to more degen proposals in DAO DAO's DAO.

it may be the case that the DAO DAO token is better at selecting *from* the registry which DAOs to Promote; that satisfices some notion of moderation (one of 'promoting the good' vs one of 'excluding the bad') while also giving the DAO DAO token a specific utility.

Ok, chatting through some of our next design efforts with @modern-edamame, here's my notes for the MVP of these features...

# Payroll UI
- Subnavigation to link to payroll
- Create new payroll button at top
- Show a list of open payroll contracts at top (Name, Description, Total Amount, Date Created, Time remaining)
- If a user is getting paid, they should be able to see available funds and claim from the UI
- If a user is a member of a DAO, their should be a button or submenu with the option to cancel payment (which will make a new proposal)
- Show expired contracts at the bottom

# SubDAOs
- Have subnavigation on a DAO page to list SubDAOs
- Create SubDAO button at top
- If not SubDAOs yet, empty state would encourage creating a SubDAO
- Indicate that a DAO is a SubDAO on the main DAO page as well as cards

# NFTs
- Design an NFT card component (Image, Name, Description, Owner)
- Subnavigation to NFT treasury
- DAOs need a way to showcase NFTs (maybe on the Treasury page), this is simply a list all the NFT cards for a DAO
- Create NFT Contract and create NFT proposal templates
Started a thread.

design question: when should we integrate actions into the `dapp`, and when should we support integrating them into other peoples' apps?

At some point, there will be so many actions for so many different apps that we won't be able to show them all easily in the DAO DAO dropdown UI. We should decide how we decide which actions end up in the DAO DAO UI, and which should be relegated to third-party applications (like JunoSwap or others).

> design question: when should we integrate actions into the dapp, and when should we support integrating them into other peoples' apps?
When they pay us or when we like them.

> At some point, there will be so many actions for so many different apps that we won't be able to show them all easily in the DAO DAO dropdown UI.
Sounds like a good design challenge.
Would be nice to search by applications, i.e. searching for "Stargaze" shows all the actions for Stargaze.
Yes! Then we implement search in actions. Show the basics and then show segmented search results. Also I like the idea of emojis associated with action groups that are all one color for the eyes.

let's go ahead with this plan for now. non-immediately actionable thoughts below.

i have a strong hunch that we will run into limitations with this approach eventually - users will, at some number of actions, have trouble knowing what to search for and/or know how to explore this UI. 

in *that* future, we might consider offloading action complexity primarily to forks of our UI. for example, a radically simply dapp UI might have:

- mint
- initiate smart contract
- custom message
- maybe some other stuff...

once dao-ui is open source, people could use it to build your own apps with your own actions. for example, junoswap might have a page that allows DAOs to create LPs.

to reiterate, these are notes for the future. i think we should continue with the searchable UI for now.

Another thing to do is add an action pack. I’m thinking this is similar to forums where you’re installing a plug-in that gives you more avatars/roles/ranks. If you want a specific set of proposal templates you can vote to add them
now THIS is a cool idea.
punting on how it would work/how people would install it on their DAO, what i love about it is that people need to decide that they want the actions
also, people can discover action packs on third-party sites.

perhaps DAOs can add action packs via governance process, and the UI can just take whatever action pack addition proposals have been passed?

pros:
- easy for UI to do
- governance is the one way DAOs can do things together

cons:
- more for governance to do
- in reality, you don't actually need to pass anything to use an action pack 

i think the con is partially mitigated if we encourage people to start subDAOs/starting subDAOs is easy.

alternatively, the UI can have a hookk that's per-session

pros:
- easy
- no governance 

cons:
- actions disappear when users change machines

finally, we can learn to stop worrying and love a little server-side state. action packs can be associated with wallet addresses in a web2 server-side db.

pros:
- easy from UX perspective
- also allows us to persist pinned DAOs across sessions (!)

cons:
- not as web3
- now we have a db to maintain
When you add a subdao, subdao action packs become available based on that subdao’s parameters
You could even choose features during setup
But this allows for third party libraries of actions and other networks

messages.content:
people seem to be consistently surprised by proposal execution. currently, proposals need to be executed, and only members of a DAO can do that executing.

my guess is that most people expect proposals to be executed as soon as they pass. how would we engineer that as a default option?

my guess:
- we have a web2 indexer that looks for passed proposals
- it has keys and executes them as soon as it notices them
@case @noahsaso wyt about this premise?
what does 'it has keys' mean
maybe you can sign up for an auto-execute bot by sending a web2 wallet like 0.000001 of your gov token
i'm not opposed, feels pretty safe
like, it's a wallet that can sign transactions
interesting! that could be a fee generating mechanism....
i like it!
it could also be free and funded by the DAO's treasury.
after all, it will require juno in the end, not DAO gov tokens.
yeah
i like this idea a lot

ooh, this also ties in with the authorizations discussion we were talking about with nicolas this morning! with his middleware you can give a bot the authorization to only execute specific actions on your DAO
yoooo

also, I guess the core issue here is that there's no listener waiting for a proposal to pass in order to execute it. I think in the case of a vote being cast that flips the status to 'Passed', the proposal's messages could then be fired, but in the case where the proposal switches to 'Passed' after expiration, then an actor has to trigger the execute
yeah, @ekez and i just talked about that irl. don't think it's worth making that execution happen automatically in some cases and not in other cases, feels like a half solution
agreed

the bot can schedule an execution check for the proposal expiration time when it notices a new proposal, and the frontend can fire an execution check (since it's web2, from the browser) when it detects a flipped vote
so it can appear quite seamless in both cases :)
beautiful

What would folks think of removing light mode from DAO DAO entirely?

Pro: less work in designs + implementation to make two themes work.
Con: are there people that feel strongly about light mode?
I only use Dark Mode but I think keeping both would be ideal for DaoDao
some applications aesthetically need both, some do well with just dark mode
like I think Spotify should have only Dark Mode because it wants to highlight the music and artists, the content itself

i am pro getting ready of the light mode as long as the dark mode follows the WCAG 1.4.3 and 1.4.11 standards:

- https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/Understanding/contrast-minimum
- https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/Understanding/non-text-contrast.html

i'm a sucker for removing code, and also notice that most 'mature' apps on the web do *not* offer a lightmode/darkmode toggle. (in fact, i have always seen the "color mode toggle" as a bit of a marker of an early-stage/small/developer-facing app).

however,  i am also a light mode user---across all apps and IDEs. i find light modes much easier on my eyes, maybe because i often work in a very bright room or outdoors. always searching for post-hoc explanations for my preferences, i googled "light mode accessibility" and found this: https://uxdesign.cc/accessibility-and-dark-ui-themes-f01001339b65

TLDR: either light or dark modes are fine, but whatever we do, let's make sure we meet the WCAG 1.4.3 and WCAG 1.4.11 standards in the text.  that seems more important than anything else. we can always add a light mode back in later.

Most of the “mature” app have the color management hidden in settings, with a default as “system” (GitHub as an exemple, at least as I can see on mac hihi).

We have a flexible app, we want to allow for customizable Single DAOs and so forth. I think we should be able to manage the color theme for us and others in the future 🙂

my thinking here: actions are more like “packs” of cosmos messages that “go together.” so far, we’ve been making actions that are more or less one message per action, which is often perfect, but sometimes we *may* want to bundle similar activities into the same action. this case is one example, another may be “manage junoswap LP,” etc.. who knows!

if it is actually an operation done by validators on the block your tokens finish unbonding it would be interesting to see what would happen if you queued up a really huge amount of unbonding operations for a specific block in the future
i have a couple things like this i want to try on a local node someday

oooh... my curiosity is piqued. here's what i can find:

https://github.com/cosmos/cosmos-sdk/blob/77a96d5fe14076cdbd4eeb7f1b29cb5687ed495f/x/staking/spec/01_state.md#unbondingdelegationqueue

so the validator stores a map of time-> delegator/validator pairs. your question is: what happens when it's `time`? my guess is... nothing. after `time`, the value at `time` can be safely removed from the queue. we all just read the state and see that it's more than time, so any transaction `delegator` does is okay, right?
that said... would be curious to check this/test it as well.

oh this is neat. nice find!

from a different part of that spec: https://github.com/cosmos/cosmos-sdk/blob/77a96d5fe14076cdbd4eeb7f1b29cb5687ed495f/x/staking/spec/02_state_transitions.md#delegations
> transfer the delegation.Amount from the delegator's account to the BondedPool or the NotBondedPool ModuleAccount depending if the validator.Status is Bonded or not
so presumably popping from that queue causes some work to be done to transfer back from the `BondedPool` to the delegator's account (bank module version)?

aha, yes, seems like that must be the case. here's a question: if i add unbondings to the queue for the same block, will the unbondings be added together? guessing yes, since the queue is a map with time as the keys... if so, would be harder to overload. you'd have to set lots of unbondings for every block - which could spread the load  out a bit more...

my thinking: it looks like the work being done is (1) removing an entry from an object (2) sending a message to transfer tokens from A to B. the way to overload these would be through numerous transactions. 

maybe... if you have lots of sibyls, get them all to unbond at the same block, you could overload something?
perhaps you could even overload the queue....
that would be an effective DoS on a validator.
